metadata.title: Bansher Ding | বাঁশের ডিং | Rural Recipes
metadata.description: Rural local recipes are integral part of Intangible Cultural Heritage and needs to be preserved and promoted. We at banglanatak dot com have been working for the past 22+ years to safeguard and promote local cultural heritages in rural spaces across India. We are now launching a new initiative of documenting rural recipes and bringing them closer to the food lovers of the world. We request all to subscribe to our new channel Rural Recipes and stay tuned there to know, learn and try out local delicacies.
ingredients_detected: Atop rice (soaked for 2-3 hours and ground into powder)

transcription_english: [00:00:12] Today, with the Rural Recipe YouTube channel, we are visiting the historic city of Cooch Behar.
[00:00:16] We will visit different places in Cooch Behar.
[00:00:29] In Rural Recipes, we go to the homes of different artists and people and try to bring you unique village foods from different places.
[00:00:59] We are in a beautiful village of North Bengal—come with me.
[00:01:11] How are you? I am fine.
[00:01:16] So we have come to your home. Yes, absolutely.
[00:01:20] You know why we have come. Yes.
[00:01:22] We are trying to bring different types of village food to you.
[00:01:29] What kind of food do you make here?
[00:01:31] In our Rajbanshi community, there is a very unique food.
[00:01:34] It is called Bansher Ding—it's a kind of pitha.
[00:01:41] Bansher Ding? Yes, Bansher Ding.
[00:01:43] The pitha is made inside the bamboo.
[00:01:47] The bamboo is stuffed with the mixture.
[00:01:49] Usually, we make it on the day after a festival.
[00:01:51] Yes, on the post-festival day.
[00:01:53] Since it is Janmashtami, I’ll make it with a twist.
[00:02:02] Wow—Janmashtami tal! I’m already thirsty.
[00:02:06] I will eat the pitha.
[00:02:07] Let’s start.
[00:02:09] First I will prepare the tal (palm fruit juice).
[00:02:11] The main ingredient is rice—
[00:02:14] atop rice powder.
[00:02:15] I will grind it.
[00:02:20] We soak the rice for 2–3 hours,
[00:02:23] then grind it.
[00:02:30] In this area, it is called Chhamgain,
[00:02:33] and many people call it Urungain.
[00:02:38] I will sieve the rice powder.
[00:02:43] After sieving, I will make the pitha with this flour.
[00:02:48] And the tal?
[00:02:49] Yes, I extracted the tal in the morning.
[00:02:53] I got this much juice from it.
[00:02:56] I have ground the coconut.
[00:02:58] Milk and sugar.
[00:03:00] And the main item is bamboo—
[00:03:03] the pitha is cooked inside bamboo.
[00:03:04] Also, cashew nuts (optional).
[00:03:06] First add the rice flour,
[00:03:15] then ground coconut,
[00:03:26] then mix with milk.
[00:03:43] Can it be made without tal?
[00:03:45] Yes, it can be made without tal.
[00:03:47] But since it’s Janmashtami, for Gopal’s offering, I’ll add tal.
[00:03:52] Mix well so there are no lumps.
[00:03:59] Add milk as needed according to quantity.
[00:04:04] I have Radha-Govinda at home; I have to offer food every day.
[00:04:15] Yes, every day.
[00:04:20] The batter is ready.
[00:04:23] Now I will add cashew nuts—optional.
[00:04:29] You can break the cashews.
[00:04:35] Ingredients are ready.
[00:04:37] Now we’ll mix well and put it on fire.
[00:04:46] We will seal the bamboo mouth with a cloth.
[00:04:52] Now we will put it on fire.
[00:04:57] (Transcript mistakenly says “fish”; it means putting the batter/mixture inside the bamboo.)
[00:05:16] How long will it take to cook? About 15 minutes.
[00:05:21] When the batter/juice starts coming out, it’s almost ready.
[00:05:28] This cooking method is called “Chubano” (covered/hidden roasting).
[00:05:34] The host asks the artist to sing a song.
[00:05:53] (Song) “We are Cooch Behari brothers…” (repeated).
[00:06:43] The Bansher Ding is ready.
[00:06:46] It looks beautiful.
[00:06:50] Let’s taste it.
[00:07:08] We will come back again with a new recipe—today we heard not only traditional food but also local traditional music.
[00:07:33] Please subscribe to our YouTube channel, like the video, and tell us in the comments how you liked today’s episode.
[00:07:43] (Song continues) “We are Cooch Behari brothers…”
